Even with a busy schedule, there are many quick and easy ways you can help your child develop their speech skills in your everyday life. Here are some ideas:

1. Talk to your child as much as possible - This can be as simple as narrating your daily activities or asking your child questions about their day. The more exposure your child has to language, the better their speech skills will develop.
2. Use descriptive language - When you talk to your child, try to use descriptive words to help them learn new vocabulary. For example, instead of saying "grab that book," you could say "can you please grab the big red book on the shelf?"
3. Encourage your child to talk about their interests - When your child is talking about something they're interested in, they are more likely to be motivated to communicate. Encourage them to talk about their favorite toys, books, or activities.
4. Sing songs and recite nursery rhymes - Singing songs and reciting nursery rhymes can help your child develop phonological awareness and practice their speech sounds. You can sing songs in the car or during bath time, or recite nursery rhymes before bedtime.
5. Read books together - Reading books is a great way to expose your child to new vocabulary and help them develop their language skills. You can read books together before bedtime or during other quiet moments in your day.

Remember that even small moments of interaction and communication can have a big impact on your child's speech development. Look for opportunities to talk and engage with your child throughout your day, and make it a priority to spend quality time with them when you can.
